title: RL33085
content: Services are a diverse group of economic activities that involve the provision of human value-added in various forms. They are intangible, cannot be stored, and must be consumed at the point of production. However, advancements in technology are reducing these restrictions on services. Services are diverse economic activities that provide human value-added, such as wholesale and retail trade, transportation, information, banking, education, healthcare, and more. Technology advancements are reducing restrictions on services. The service sector in the U.S. economy is significant, accounting for 83% of nonagricultural payroll jobs and 65% of GDP in 2010. Various services like transportation, banking, education, healthcare, and more play a crucial role in running large economies. The service sector in the U.S. economy, including food and accommodation services, construction, communication, and public administration, is increasingly significant. In 2010, it accounted for 83% of nonagricultural payroll jobs and 65% of GDP. Financial services, like banking and investment, are crucial for capital flow in the economy. Delivery services are essential for ensuring the smooth production and distribution of goods. Financial services, delivery services, and distribution services are vital for the economy, facilitating capital flow, ensuring goods availability, and providing goods to consumers. Inefficiencies in these industries could have adverse effects on the economy. U.S. trade in services plays a significant role in the overall economy. Distribution services, including retail and wholesale services, ensure the availability of goods to consumers. Inefficiencies in these industries could have negative impacts on the economy. U.S. trade in services, while smaller than trade in goods, accounted for 30% of total U.S. exports and 17% of total U.S. imports in 2010. Many service providers prefer to establish a presence in the country of operation due to the direct contact required between supplier and consumer. In 2010, services accounted for 30% of total U.S. exports and 17% of total U.S. imports. Service providers often establish a presence in the country of the consumer for direct contact and access to expert knowledge. In 2010, services accounted for 30% of total U.S. exports and 17% of total U.S. imports. Service providers often establish a presence in the country of the consumer for direct contact and access to expert knowledge. Cross-border services trade data may not capture all trade in services, as some services require a direct presence in the consumer's country for legal, accounting, and construction services. Data from foreign affiliates of U.S.-owned companies and U.S. affiliates of foreign-owned firms provide a more accurate measurement of trade in services. In 2008, U.S. firms sold $1,137 billion in services to foreigners through their majority-owned foreign affiliates, while foreign firms sold U.S. residents $727 billion in services through their majority-owned foreign affiliates located in the United States. This data complements cross-border services trade data, providing a more accurate measurement of trade in services. In 2008, U.S. firms sold $1,137 billion in services to foreigners through their majority-owned foreign affiliates, while foreign firms sold U.S. residents $727 billion in services through their majority-owned foreign affiliates located in the United States. This data complements cross-border services trade data, providing a more accurate measurement of trade in services. Additionally, there are two other modes of services delivery through the temporary movement of consumers to the location of the provider and the temporary movement of the provider to the location of the consumer. The Trade Act of 1974 instructed the Administration to promote an agreement on trade in services under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) during the Tokyo Round negotiations, laying the foundation for multilateral negotiations in services trade. The seeds for multilateral negotiations in services trade were planted more than a quarter century ago during the Trade Act of 1974, instructing the Administration to promote an agreement on trade in services under GATT. Developing countries were hesitant to include services in negotiations due to less advanced service sectors compared to industrialized countries. During the Tokyo Round negotiations in 1979, services were not included in the agreement. However, the United States and other industrialized countries pushed for services to be covered in later negotiations. Developing countries were initially hesitant due to their less advanced service sectors. Services were eventually included in the Uruguay Round negotiations in 1986, leading to the establishment of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) and the World Trade Organization (WTO) to administer it. During the Uruguay Round negotiations in 1986, services were included, leading to the creation of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) and the World Trade Organization (WTO). Trade scholar Geza Feketekuty identified three main challenges in constructing rules for international trade in services. Trade scholar Geza Feketekuty identifies challenges in constructing rules for international trade in services, including targeting domestic regulations as barriers, distinguishing legitimate regulations from protectionism, and considering services transactions behind customs borders. The challenges in constructing rules for international trade in services include distinguishing legitimate regulations from protectionism, considering services transactions behind customs borders, and adapting to technology advances like the internet making non-tradable services tradable. The challenges in constructing rules for international trade in services include adapting to technology advances like the internet making non-tradable services tradable and the rapid introduction of services products that can be "outsourced" across borders. Effective trade rules need to be flexible yet provide meaningful discipline to WTO members' activities. The GATS structure recognizes that most services transactions occur within borders, and barriers to trade in services are within customs barriers. Trade rules must consider different modes of delivery to identify barriers for foreign service providers. The GATS categorizes delivery modes into four categories. The GATS categorizes delivery modes into four categories to identify barriers for foreign service providers. One mode is cross-border supply (mode 1), where the service is supplied from one country to another. The GATS categorizes delivery modes into four categories to identify barriers for foreign service providers. The modes include cross-border supply (mode 1), consumption abroad (mode 2), and commercial presence (mode 3). Chicago is hired by a client in Mexico to design a building. The U.S. firm does the design in Chicago and sends the blueprints to its client in Mexico. A Mexican client travels to the United States to obtain the services of a U.S. architectural firm. A U.S. architectural firm establishes a subsidiary in Mexico to sell services to local clients. Individual supplier travels temporarily to the country of the consumer. The General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) is a multilateral framework among 153 WTO members for government policies affecting trade in services. It includes modes such as commercial presence (mode 3) where a service supplier establishes a subsidiary in another country, and presence of natural persons (mode 4) where an individual supplier travels temporarily to provide services. The GATS is still evolving. The GATS is a multilateral framework among 153 WTO members for government policies affecting trade in services. It aims to promote economic development, trade liberalization, and the right of member governments to regulate services sectors. Part I defines the scope of the GATS, including its application to all services except those under government authority, government barriers to trade, and all modes of service delivery. Part II presents principles and obligations that apply to all services sectors, regardless of whether they are listed in a member's schedule of commitments. Part II of the GATS outlines principles and obligations that apply to all services sectors, regardless of whether they are specifically listed in a member's schedule of commitments. The GATS Part III establishes market access and national treatment obligations for members, prohibiting less favorable treatment and placing limits on suppliers of services from other member countries. The GATS Part III establishes market access and national treatment obligations for members, ensuring equal treatment for service providers from other member countries and allowing for negotiations to reduce trade barriers. The GATS Part III establishes market access and national treatment obligations for members, ensuring equal treatment for service providers from other member countries. Each WTO member must submit a schedule of commitments (SC) during the GATS negotiations, with new members required to do so upon accession. The SC is a crucial part of the GATS, similar to tariff schedules but more complex for services. The SC is a crucial part of the GATS, required for new members upon accession. The Schedule of Commitments (SC) in the GATS is more detailed than tariff schedules, outlining restrictions on market access and national treatment for various service sectors. It is divided into four columns, with the first column listing sectors/subsectors, the second and third columns detailing restrictions for each mode of delivery, and the fourth column listing additional commitments. The schedule is also divided into two parts, with the first part focusing on horizontal commitments that apply to all service sectors. In September 2007, the chairman of the trade in services negotiations started drafting an agreement, but by the end of the year, countries were still divided on key objectives. Developed countries, like the United States, pushed for binding commitments on trade in services, while developing countries, such as Argentina, opposed these benchmarks without greater commitments from developed nations.
